{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3395883,"name":"sam liu","username":"catrix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/dbc845/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-06T05:48:05.533Z","cooked":"

Hey everyone! I’m the programmer of Team 5516 “Iron Maple”.
Our team has developed an all-real robot simulation and we are happy to share our progress!
Previous FRC simulators like MoSimulator run on game engines and are separate from the actual robot code. In contrast, our simulator is entirely embedded in the Java robot code and has the same operating logic as the real robot.

It runs directly on WPISim and renders the image using AdvantageScope. We used dyn4j, an open-source 2d physics engine to simulate the physics behavior of the chassis and to detect collisions.

The simulator is part of our open-source drive-base project Phantom.

That’s exactly what we’re working on, Shenzhen-Robotics-Alliance/Maple-Swerve-Skeleton: Iron Maple’s swerve-drive skeleton project, based on 6328’s Advanced Swerve Drive Example (github.com).
It’s a drop-in replacement for 6328’s Advanced Swerve Drive Example but with our physics simulation engine. It’s not finished yet; we plan to release it later this month.
